messageBody:
Oh I would never suggest removing Awe, Ah, Why or any letter from
QS merely because I personally only use them in the standard
spellings. It's just amusing to be reminded every time I glance at
that alphabet that my accent does not embrace all English sounds. All
the more amusing since mine, being Californian, is the accent
constantly pouring forth from TV and movies.
But yes, in normal speech the sound I make for my doctor "ahh" is
the same as the feeling toward divinity "awe". If one really
concentrates and speaks in an unnatural way one can possibly manage a
difference but it's not the norm. Yes nautical is pronounced not-ikol
by my kind and "bass" the fish sounds different than "bass" the
instrument.
But yes, to my mind English orthography is so hopelessly messed up
that written words bear only a passing resemblance to their
pronunciation. Especially vowels and diphthongs. A situation which
must continue to worsen so long as orthography remains frozen but
pronunciation in this thoroughly living language with its rapidly
growing number of speakers continues to evolve. Hence the value of the
Shaw/Read program.
Which, incidentally, touches on another point: I must comment that
the Read/Shaw agenda was vastly more ambitious than popping out yet
another shorthand. As every reference to purpose made by the original
contributors indicates, the plan was to reform and rationalize
English and incidentally give English and English speakers some of the
advantages found in more systematic writing forms.
Of course, as we all know, the cursive form of writing QS was,
among other things, intentionally devised to be fast just as cursive
orthodox English is. And the complexity of word formation in senior QS
is comparable to shorthand. This may occasionally give rise to the
misimpression that the project's purpose was to be a shorthand but
Senior QS is no more a shorthand than cursive orthodox English.
Besides, it's unimaginable that Shaw would allocate funds in his will
for something as trivial as a new shorthand. Growing peas maybe, but
never shorthand ;->
QS could be used as a shorthand of course but it is far more
important to use it as a toy, as odd as that may sound, because as
such it is a great stimulus to the much need discourse about reform to
English and the production of ideas that may be useful when one or
another English speaking country finally bites the bullet and moves
forward with reform. The Dutch did after all.


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, pgabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:
>
> Anthony:
>
> I agree totally with you that the ligatures have nothing to do with a
> changed sound. They are simply easy and quick ways to write these
> vowels that combine with "r."
>
> And hearing someone's accent is cool if if it is not 100% correct or as
> exact as an IPA transcription.
>
> Finding it funny that there are two letters you don't use is like
> thinking it funny that the British pronounce words differently than
> Americans do. A well designed alphabet should be able to map the major
> dialects of all the speakers of the language should it not? Many
> English speakers no longer use the "hw" sound, but for those of us who
> do, a suggestion that it should be excluded from the alphabet will fall
> on deaf ears.
>
> I must ask one question since you brought it up. I understand that you
> substitute the vowel sound of "Ah" in place of the traditional "Awe"
> typically represented by "au," as in "nautical." I first became really
> aware of this when a TV announcer in a frequently-aired commercial said
> "nautical" as if it were spelled "knotical," which left me confused
as I
> did not understand why someone would pronounce a word whose spelling
> clearly seemed - at least to me - to indicate it was a diphthong as a
> short o sound. What I am wondering is how do you pronounce the word
> "awe" itself as in what one experiences in connection with the deity?
> Does that also come out as "ah"? I have difficulty imagining someone
> saying, "I stand in ah before God." To me that is the sound the doctor
> tells you to make before using a tongue depressor, not a separate word
> by itself.
>
> I know this probably sounds parochial, but I have never had anyone
> answer this question before. And if, in fact, people whose dialect has
> undergone this merger still pronounce the word "awe" as a stand-alone
> diphthong, why would they eschew it in other settings, such as
> "nautical." The answer, I would suspect, is that English
orthography is
> so hopelessly messed up that it causes no cognitive dissonance to
> pronounce the same letters one way in one word and quite differently in
> other words. The average person doesn't even notice the problem.
>
> Paige
>
> Anthony Grahn wrote:
> >
> > Personally I like to think of Quickscript writing in a tape
> > recorder metaphor with the reluctant exception of the senior standard
> > spellings. Not every one follows this philosophy and they have good
> > reason since there are certainly drawbacks. One rarely mentioned and
> > irrelevant but hyper cool benefit though, is that you get to really
> > hear the accent of the writer when you read the text. Something which
> > never occurs with orthodox English.
> > What to do with the ligatures is a good question I think. I
believe
> > they were conceived as a few connected forms to be used in junior.
> > _We_ think of them as ligatures because we have an electo-typesetting
> > bias. But the QM seems only to think of them a two letters joined for
> > speed. IMO, I believe it might be best to view them as typcaster's
> > tools with pronunciation identical to the separate letters they
represent.
> > And what is the IPA pronunciation of each letter? Another great
> > point. Attached is a phonetic correlation I put together to map the
> > sounds as I think Read intended them. I did this by looking at the
> > pronunciation of the examples and letter names as they were likely
> > pronounced in his time and place which is to say I looked up each one
> > of his words in the Oxford dictionary. Alas it does not exactly match
> > my 21st cen west coast pronunciation either which in some cases is
> > really annoying. In my personal speech "Ox", "Ah", and "Awe" are
> > pronounced the same and having two letters in my alphabet that I
never
> > use (although others may) feels funny.
> >
> >
> > */John Cowan <cowan@...>/* wrote:
> >
> > othermale scripsit:
> >
> > > Thus "eight" (name of a letter in QM) and
> > > "pair" (example used for a ligature in QM) have the same
> > pronunciation
> > > in upper-class-British English but differ in 21st century
American
> > > English.
> >
> > I'm definitely American and 21st-century, and for me they are the
> > same.
> > In terms of Wells lexical sets, SQUARE is like FACE but with
an /r/,
> > rather than DRESS with an /r/.
> >
> > --
> > John Cowan http://ccil.org/~cowan <http://ccil.org/%7Ecowan>
> > cowan@... <mailto:cowan%40ccil.org>
> > There are books that are at once excellent and boring. Those
that at
> > once leap to the mind are Thoreau's Walden, Emerson's Essays,
George
> > Eliot's Adam Bede, and Landor's Dialogues. --Somerset Maugham
> >
